Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery band-cup or skyphos; interior glazed black; exterior: part of glazed black zone above frieze with black-figure decoration consisting of warrior to right (upper body remaining) wearing a Corinthian helmet with added red dots on crest and on beard; holding spear in raised right hand; wearing a chiton in added white; at left, arm and helmet crest of warrior to left; at right, three small black dots, perhaps 'nonsense inscription'.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: CVA Brussels III / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Belgique (p. 20, pl. 27, no. 19)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 476, no. B824)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1406) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
